content.caption: <a id="h.zcmypmslennq"/>Making a BDN multimedia project is easy

By using a few simple styles, you can do a lot to design how our multimedia projects work. Right from the comfort of Google Docs. This doc is a template that you can copy to start your own multimedia project. Once you’re ready to get your friendly user experience manager involved, fill out the multimedia project request form.
To begin, you’ll need to format the Google Doc with your story using the rules described below.
<a id="h.xckkenvpc41b"/>Here’s how it works
Content is split into sections by using the “subtitle” style from the dropdown menu at the top.

So every time you want to break your story into a new chunk, make sure you apply that style. You can paste images in the doc, like the one above, to test out how things look and pacing, and they won’t show up in the final project.

Not all formatting you use in this doc will show up in your multimedia project. That’s part by design. Links, bold and italics will come through. Ordered and unordered lists will come through. Most other formatting, however, will not, so you can go wild experimenting with design in the doc.
<a id="h.yh70p2aiccr8"/>Using multimedia assets in your story
To use any multimedia options, you’ll need to use these special codes.
This is my photo!

I know they can be kinda hard to read (let’s work on that!) but here’s basically how they work. It’s the same code no matter what type of asset you have — just some types of media, like videos, have additional attributes.

• The filename is the Merlin ID of the photo, or the full url of the video file (Youtube is OK!).
  • The filetype can be video, photo, pullquote, youtube or graphic.
  • The size can be small, medium or large.
  • The orientation can be full, left or right. (This is for laptop and bigger screens, usually.) Full means that it is going to be the full width of the story — centered.
  • The caption should describe the photo. Be careful with using quotations and apostrophes in the caption, because that will break the formatting of the code. If you need to use it, make sure you proceed them with a backslash (\). If you do not want a caption on your video, just leave this blank: “”.
  • The credit is the entire credit line, e.g. Brian Feulner | BDN Photo. It should include who gave us the photo and the name of the person, if applicable. If you don’t want to include a credit on your video, just leave this blank: “”.
  • The poster field is only used for videos. It’s the Merlin ID you want to use to show the preview for the video.
Each field is preceded with the name of the field, then a colon, then the value of the field, separated by a comma. It must all be on one line. The code is wrapped with curly braces.
<a id="h.w9gq8sseru4p"/>On the subject of video

A great multimedia piece will have video, and the video should be cut so it complements the story. That means we understand we need collaborative editing, and the process of uploading files through the video uploader is time consuming for rough cuts.
However, we need the videos to be available in a public place so people can see them!

I used to have a whole thing in here about using Google Drive to host the video, but I took it out because it was a lot complicated than what I had thought. Any file system that can host a video file is fine. Dropbox isn’t ideal because of the bandwidth cap.
Here’s what the video code looks like:
FYI, any location where you can upload a video file directly will work — Dropbox just isn’t a viable solution with bandwidth capping).
You can also do it by just referencing the video ID number from the video.
See? That was easy.
<a id="h.8cybu59p34ur"/>When you’re ready for final videos
Go ahead and upload it through the video uploader.
Then go in Wordpress and find your uploaded video file. Preview that file and then go into the embed code and find the URL to the iframe.
The way that videos are input is a little different. I need the video to be put in Wordpress with our video uploader:
http://bangordailynews.com/apps/videos/
Mark it somehow to say DO NOT PUBLISH. In order to do the subsequent steps, you’ll need to have at least
Then when it’s done, update the doc where the video is with a link to the video file itself. To do this, go to the video preview once it’s been uploaded and then hit the share button.
Then copy the EMBED code from the video. You want to go to the link in the iframe, but put view-source: before it. (Make sure you're using Chrome)
Then do Ctrl + F (find) and search the page for m4v
THEN copy everything in that file field for m4v. (Almost done). It should look something like this:
So THEN you're going to paste that in the doc where the filename is for the video code. BUT you want to take out all the back slashes (\). So it should look like a normal URL, e.g.
http://watchvideo.bangordailynews.com/bdn/2015/01/Clearingsnowfromthesidewalks_1873806.m4v
(To make sure you did that last step right, you should be able to copy the link you've built and go to it in a web browser and it will show you a video).

You can also just include a Youtube video! Depending on your objectives, this may or may not be a better solution than uploading your video to the BDN. Talk about your options with your friendly user experience manager.
<a id="h.y52hndcx5zcz"/>One last thing

Like I said in the first chapter, you can add comments, paste images, add line breaks, whatever and you don’t have to worry about them showing up in the final project. This is a great way to annotate and visualize how you want a project to come together without worrying about it breaking the final piece.
When you’re ready to start importing the project, make sure to make this file public to anyone with a link! That way the importer will be able to grab it.
To do this, go to file > publish to the web (and publish when changes are made > then grab the link there.
You’re ready to make a multimedia project! Now head to the multimedia project request form and fill out the details about this project.
